abstract.p: Elisabeth Ginsburg offers advice on using larkspur in landscape (S)

block.p: I have a problem with delphiniums. Despite cosseting, staking, hoping and praying, they simply do not succeed in my garden. That is all right; now I have larkspur.

Larkspur (Consolida orientalis) is tall and elegant, with flower stems that reach two to four feet. It comes in blues, shades of purple, pink and white. The feathery foliage, long stems and abundant spurred blossoms make it perfect for arrangements.
I have a problem with delphiniums. Despite cosseting, staking, hoping and praying, they simply do not succeed in my garden. That is all right; now I have larkspur.

Larkspur (Consolida orientalis) is tall and elegant, with flower stems that reach two to four feet. It comes in blues, shades of purple, pink and white. The feathery foliage, long stems and abundant spurred blossoms make it perfect for arrangements.

The best thing about larkspur is that the seeds can be sown directly into the ground in early spring or fall. If planted in spring, the plants will flower the same season and self-seed with wild abandon. By late summer, little ferny seedlings will have emerged from the ground. Next year you will have at least twice the number of larkspur that you had this year.
